channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lens Blog: Looking for the Enduring Photo in Gaza
item.description: Tyler Hicks, a Times photographer who covered the first two weeks of the conflict in Gaza, spoke about his experiences.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Palestinians in Gaza City prepared to bury a member of Hamas. July 12, 2014.

item.title: World Briefing: British Military Jet Escorts Airliner After Bomb Threat
item.description: A Royal Air Force fighter flew next to a Qatar Airways flight that was about to land in Manchester after a bomb threat that turned out to be a hoax.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Buddhist Sect Leader Detained During Raid
item.description: Wu Zeheng, a Buddhist master who has long been at odds with the Chinese government, was taken into police custody last week after the police staged a coordinated raid on his group, Huazang Dharma.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS
item.media:description: Police officers on July 29 searching a house that some of Wu Zeheng’s followers had rented for the summer to be near his residence in Zhuhai.

item.title: U.S. General Is Reportedly Killed by an Afghan Soldier
item.description: The United States Army major general, reportedly shot at a military academy on the outskirts of Kabul, was the highest-ranking member of the American military to die in the Afghanistan war.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and HARIS KAKAR
item.media:description: A NATO soldier opened fire toward journalists near the main gate of Camp Qargha on Tuesday after a shooting at the military training academy outside Kabul.

item.title: Divers Fail to Find Bangladesh Ferry That Capsized
item.description: Rescue workers fought against powerful currents on Tuesday in hopes of recovering bodies from the ferry that sank, leaving more than 120 passengers missing and presumed dead.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People gather near where a ferry capsized on the Padma River south of Dhaka, Bangladesh. More than 120 passengers are presumed dead.

item.title: Japan Keeps Door to Russia Open While Imposing Sanctions
item.description: The new measures, more limited than those announced last month by the United States, will freeze assets in Japan of groups and individuals involved in Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: The cabinet of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe imposed new sanctions against Russia on Tuesday.

item.title: Tunisia, in Political Transition, Fears Attacks by Citizens Radicalized Abroad
item.description: For a country of only 11 million people, Tunisia has supplied a disproportionate number of fighters to the Islamist cause in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Demonstrators carried flags of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria in June in Mosul, Iraq. For a small country of only 11 million, Tunisia has supplied a disproportionate number of fighters to the Islamist cause in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Formula One Chief Bernie Ecclestone Settles Bribery Case for $100 Million
item.description: A German judge formally ended the trial of the billionaire Ecclestone without ruling on whether he was guilty.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Cease-Fire in Gaza Begins, and Israel Says Its Troops Are Gone
item.description: As a 72-hour cease-fire mediated by Egypt took hold, Israel announced that it had withdrawn its forces from Gaza and Hamas said it would engage in talks on a lasting peace arrangement.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers left Israel’s border with Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Muslim Minister Quits British Government to Protest Gaza Policies
item.description: Sayeeda Warsi, the first Muslim to join the British cabinet, called Prime Minister David Cameron’s response to Gaza “morally indefensible.”
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: British Parties Try to Entice Scots
item.description: With about six weeks to go before a referendum on independence, new powers were pledged for the Scottish Parliament, contingent on a “no” vote.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Quake Scene, Leader’s Dip in the Mud Gets Close Attention
item.description: Since coming to office last year Premier Li Keqiang has stepped into the footsteps of his predecessor, Wen Jiabao, who was known as China’s “consoler in chief.”
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: China Investigating Canadian Couple on Suspicion of Espionage
item.description: Kevin and Julia Dawn Garratt are “suspected of collecting and stealing intelligence material,” the Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Familiar Script in China As a ‘Tiger’ Is Taken Down
item.description: Zhou Yongkang’s fate fits a pattern found with a succession of ousted officials stretching back to the purge of Gang of Four in 1976 and much earlier.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhou Yongkang delivering a speech in Beijing on May 18, 2012, when he was still a member of the Communist Party Politburo's Standing Committee.

item.title: Gaza War Strains Relations Between U.S. and Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government has largely dismissed American efforts to end the violence, leaving U.S. officials to seethe on the sidelines.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama has had few levers to influence Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government on the current conflict in Gaza.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shadowy World for Chinese Surrogates
item.description: Though illegal, surrogacy has increased in China thanks to couples waiting until their late 30s to have children, which makes it harder to conceive.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Shaken by Case of Muslim Men Missing in Iraq
item.description: The apparent online recruitment of four Indian Muslims to join the fight in Iraq has shocked their home country, which had believed that it was immune from such defections.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muslim men left a mosque last month in Kalyan, India, on the outskirts of Mumbai. Four young men from the city were apparently recruited over the Internet to fight with Islamists in Iraq.

item.title: World Briefing: China: Earthquake Survivors Rescued
item.description: Rescuers found more than 30 survivors on Monday in southwestern China after an earthquake killed at least 398 people and injured more than 1,800.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Azerbaijan and Armenia Trade Attacks
item.description: Azerbaijan and Armenia on Monday both reported more losses in a sharp escalation of fighting over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, with 18 soldiers now confirmed dead.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lax Quarantine Undercuts Ebola Fight in Africa
item.description: Sierra Leone, the nation with the most cases of the disease, has banned many public gatherings and set strict quarantine rules, but health officials are deeply worried by loose enforcement efforts.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Relatives of Saudatu Koroma, who health officials say died of Ebola, at their home in Freetown.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Atef Abu Saif: Life and Death in the Gaza Strip
item.description: Life goes on, even as death intrudes, in the Jabaliya refugee community, where tens of thousands of Palestinians have been caught in the running battle between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By ATEF ABU SAIF

item.title: Buildup Makes Russia Battle-Ready for Ukraine
item.description: Adding battalions near the border with Ukraine could allow Russia to launch a cross-border incursion there with little or no warning, Western officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Ukraine Rebels Enlisting ‘Punishment Brigades’ for Support Work
item.description: Glum-looking detainees, often stripped to their underwear, can be seen around Donetsk digging ditches, clearing brush and peeling potatoes.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Russian rebel in Ukraine stood by two men who were held for a curfew violation and drunkenness, as they cut grass outside of Makeevka, in the southeast.

item.title: Disputes Threaten to Derail Audit of Afghanistan Vote
item.description: Three weeks after Secretary of State John Kerry brokered a deal to impose a monitored review of the presidential election runoff, the process came close to collapse over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Votes cast in the Afghan presidential runoff were scrutinized by election officials on Sunday.

item.title: Visit From Indian Premier Signals a Political Shift in Nepal
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi appealed to both politicians and devout Hindus during a recent visit as he announced plans to increase ties between the countries.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited Pashupatinath Temple in Nepal on Monday.
